column3: Description
column5: Cluster
column6: Unit
column8: Number of Class Sessions Including Review and Assessment

column3: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.
column6: Topic 3: Numeric and Algebraic Expressions

column3: Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.
column6: Topic 3: Numeric and Algebraic Expressions

column3: Write expressions that record operations with numbers and with letters standing for numbers. For example, express the calculation “Subtract y from 5” as 5 – y.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.
column6: Topic 3: Numeric and Algebraic Expressions

column3: Write expressions that record operations with numbers and with letters standing for numbers. For example, express the calculation “Subtract y from 5” as 5 – y.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.
column6: Topic 7: Solve Area, Surface Area, and Volume Problems

column3: Identify parts of an expression using mathematical terms (sum, term, product, factor, quotient, and coefficient); view one or more parts of an expression as a single entity.  For example, describe the expression 2(8 + 7) as a product of two factors; view (8 + 7) as both a single entity and a sum of two terms.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.
column6: Topic 3: Numeric and Algebraic Expressions

column3:
Evaluate expressions at specific values of their variables. Include expressions that arise from
formulas used in real-world problems. Perform arithmetic operations, including those involving
whole-number exponents, in the conventional order when there are no parentheses to specify a
particular order (Order of Operations). For example, use the formulas V = s^3 and A = 6s^2 to find the volume and surface area of a cube with sides of length s = ½ .
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.
column6: Topic 3: Numeric and Algebraic Expressions

column3:
Evaluate expressions at specific values of their variables. Include expressions that arise from
formulas used in real-world problems. Perform arithmetic operations, including those involving
whole-number exponents, in the conventional order when there are no parentheses to specify a
particular order (Order of Operations). For example, use the formulas V = s^3 and A = 6s^2 to find the volume and surface area of a cube with sides of length s = ½ .
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.
column6: Topic 7: Solve Area, Surface Area, and Volume Problems

column3: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions. For example, apply the distributive property to the expression 3(2 + x) to produce the equivalent expression 6 + 3x; apply the distributive property to the expression 24x + 18y to produce the equivalent expression 6(4x + 3y); apply properties of operations to y + y + y to produce the equivalent expression 3y.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.
column6: Topic 3: Numeric and Algebraic Expressions

column3: Identify when two expressions are equivalent (i.e., when the two expressions name the same number regardless of which value is substituted into them). For example, the expressions y + y + y and 3y are equivalent because they name the same number regardless of which number y stands for.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.
column6: Topic 3: Numeric and Algebraic Expressions

column3: Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: Which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.
column5: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.
column6: Topic 4: Represent and Solve Equations and Inequalities

column3: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.
column5: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.
column6: Topic 3: Numeric and Algebraic Expressions

column3: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.
column5: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.
column6: Topic 7: Solve Area, Surface Area, and Volume Problems

column3: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q, and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.
column5: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.
column6: Topic 4: Represent and Solve Equations and Inequalities

column3: Write an inequality of the form x > c or x < c to represent a constraint or condition in a real-world or mathematical problem. Recognize that inequalities of the form x > c or x < c have infinitely many solutions; represent solutions of such inequalities on number line diagrams.
column5: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.
column6: Topic 4: Represent and Solve Equations and Inequalities

column3: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation. For example, in a problem involving motion at constant speed, list and graph ordered pairs of distances and times, and write the equation d = 65t to represent the relationship between distance and time.
column5: Represent and analyze quantitative relationships between dependent and independent variables.
column6: Topic 4: Represent and Solve Equations and Inequalities

column3: Find the area of right triangles, other triangles, special quadrilaterals, and polygons by composing into rectangles or decomposing into triangles and other shapes; apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
column5: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area, and volume.
column6: Topic 7: Solve Area, Surface Area, and Volume Problems

column3: Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths by packing it with unit cubes of the appropriate unit fraction edge lengths, and show that the volume is the same as would be found by multiplying the edge lengths of the prism. Apply the formulas V = lwh and V = Bh to find volumes of right rectangular prisms with fractional edge lengths in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
column5: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area, and volume.
column6: Topic 7: Solve Area, Surface Area, and Volume Problems

column3: Draw polygons in the coordinate plane given coordinates for the vertices; use coordinates to find the length of a side joining points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
column5: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area, and volume.
column6: Topic 7: Solve Area, Surface Area, and Volume Problems

column3: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface areas of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.
column5: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, surface area, and volume.
column6: Topic 7: Solve Area, Surface Area, and Volume Problems

column3: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to divide fractions by fractions.
column6: Topic 1: Use Positive Rational Numbers

column3: Fluently divide multi-digit numbers using the standard algorithm.
column5: Compute fluently with multi-digit numbers and find common factors and multiples.
column6: Topic 1: Use Positive Rational Numbers

column3: Fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide multi-digit decimals using the standard algorithm for each operation.
column5: Compute fluently with multi-digit numbers and find common factors and multiples.
column6: Topic 1: Use Positive Rational Numbers

column3: Use prime factorization to find the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100 and the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12. Use the distributive property to express a sum of two whole numbers 1–100 with a common factor as a multiple of a sum of two relatively prime numbers. For example, express 36 + 8 as 4(9 + 2).
column5: Compute fluently with multi-digit numbers and find common factors and multiples.
column6: Topic 3: Numeric and Algebraic Expressions

column3: Understand that positive and negative numbers are used together to describe quantities having opposite directions or values (e.g., temperature above/below zero, elevation above/below sea level, credits/debits, and positive/negative electric charge). Use positive and negative numbers (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals) to represent quantities in real-world contexts, explaining the meaning of zero in each situation.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 2: Integers and Rational Numbers

column3:
Understand a rational number as a point on the number line. Extend number line diagrams and
coordinate axes familiar from previous grades to represent points on the line and in the plane with
negative number coordinates.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 2: Integers and Rational Numbers

column3: . Recognize opposite signs of numbers as indicating locations on opposite sides of 0 on the number line; recognize that the opposite of the opposite of a number is the number itself, e.g., –(–3) = 3, and that zero is its own opposite.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 2: Integers and Rational Numbers

column3: Understand signs of numbers in ordered pairs as indicating locations in quadrants of the coordinate plane; recognize that when two ordered pairs differ only by signs, the locations of the points are related by reflections across one or both axes.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 2: Integers and Rational Numbers

column3: Find and position integers and other rational numbers on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram; find and position pairs of integers and other rational numbers on a coordinate plane.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 2: Integers and Rational Numbers

column3: Find and position integers and other rational numbers on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram; find and position pairs of integers and other rational numbers on a coordinate plane.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 7: Solve Area, Surface Area, and Volume Problems

column3: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 2: Integers and Rational Numbers

column3:
Interpret statements of inequality as statements about the relative positions of two numbers on
a number line diagram.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 2: Integers and Rational Numbers

column3: Write, interpret, and explain statements of order for rational numbers in real-world contexts.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 2: Integers and Rational Numbers

column3: Understand the absolute value of a rational number as its distance from 0 on the number line; interpret absolute value as magnitude for a positive or negative quantity in a real-world situation. For example, for an account balance of –30 dollars, write |–30| = 30 to describe the size of the debt in dollars.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 2: Integers and Rational Numbers

column3:
Distinguish comparisons of absolute value from statements about order.
For example, recognize that an account balance less than –30 dollars represents a debt greater than 30 dollars.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 2: Integers and Rational Numbers

column3: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by graphing points in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane. Include use of coordinates and absolute value to find distances between points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 2: Integers and Rational Numbers

column3: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by graphing points in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane. Include use of coordinates and absolute value to find distances between points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate.
column5: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to the system of rational numbers.
column6: Topic 7: Solve Area, Surface Area, and Volume Problems

column3: Understand the concept of a ratio including the distinctions between part:part and part:whole and the value of a ratio; part/part and part/whole. Use ratio language to describe a ratio relationship between two quantities.
column5: Understand ratio and rate concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.
column6: Topic 5: Understand and Use Ratio and Rate

column3: Understand the concept of a unit rate a/b associated with a ratio a:b with b not 0, and use rate language in the context of a ratio relationship, including the use of units.
column5: Understand ratio and rate concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.
column6: Topic 5: Understand and Use Ratio and Rate

column3: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world and mathematical problems, e.g., by reasoning about tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations.
column5: Understand ratio and rate concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.
column6: Topic 5: Understand and Use Ratio and Rate

column3: Make tables of equivalent ratios relating quantities with whole-number measurements. Find missing values in the tables, and plot the pairs of values on the coordinate plane. Use tables to compare ratios.
column5: Understand ratio and rate concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.
column6: Topic 5: Understand and Use Ratio and Rate

column3: Solve unit rate problems, including those involving unit pricing, and constant speed. For example, if it took seven hours to mow four lawns, then, at that rate, how many lawns could be mowed in 35 hours? At what rate were lawns being mowed?
column5: Understand ratio and rate concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.
column6: Topic 5: Understand and Use Ratio and Rate

column3: Find a percent of a quantity as a rate per 100 (e.g., 30% of a quantity means 30∕100 times the quantity); solve problems involving finding the whole, given a part and the percent.
column5: Understand ratio and rate concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.
column6: Topic 6: Understand and Use Percent

column3: Use ratio reasoning to convert measurement units within and between measurement systems; manipulate and transform units appropriately when multiplying or dividing quantities. For example, Malik is making a recipe, but he cannot find his measuring cups! He has, however, found a tablespoon. His cookbook says that 1 cup = 16 tablespoons. Explain how he could use the tablespoon to measure out the following ingredients: two cups of flour, ½ cup sunflower seed, and 1¼ cup of oatmeal.
column5: Understand ratio and rate concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.
column6: Topic 5: Understand and Use Ratio and Rate

column3: Solve problems that relate the mass of an object to its volume.
column5: Understand ratio and rate concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.
column6: Topic 6: Understand and Use Percent

column3: Recognize a statistical question as one that anticipates variability in the data related to the question and accounts for it in the answers. For example, “How old am I?” is not a statistical question, but “How old are the students in my school?” is a statistical question because one anticipates variability in students’ ages.
column5: Develop understanding of statistical variability.
column6: Topic 8: Display, Describe, and Summarize Data

column3: Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution, which can be described by its center (median, mean, and/or mode), spread (range, interquartile range), and overall shape.
column5: Develop understanding of statistical variability.
column6: Topic 8: Display, Describe, and Summarize Data

column3: Recognize that a measure of center for a numerical data set summarizes all of its values with a single number, while a measure of variation describes how its values vary with a single number.
column5: Develop understanding of statistical variability.
column6: Topic 8: Display, Describe, and Summarize Data

column3: Display numerical data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box plots.
column5: Summarize and describe distributions.
column6: Topic 8: Display, Describe, and Summarize Data

column3: Read and interpret circle graphs.
column5: Summarize and describe distributions.
column6: Topic 8: Display, Describe, and Summarize Data

column3: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context, such as by:
column5: Summarize and describe distributions.
column6: Topic 8: Display, Describe, and Summarize Data

column3: Reporting the number of observations.
column5: Summarize and describe distributions.
column6: Topic 8: Display, Describe, and Summarize Data

column3: Describing the nature of the attribute under investigation, including how it was measured and its units of measurement.
column5: Summarize and describe distributions.
column6: Topic 8: Display, Describe, and Summarize Data

column3: Giving quantitative measures of center (median, and/or mean) and variability (range and/or interquartile range), as well as describing any overall pattern and any striking deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data were gathered.
column5: Summarize and describe distributions.
column6: Topic 8: Display, Describe, and Summarize Data

column3: Relating the choice of measures of center and variability to the shape of the data distribution and the context in which the data were gathered.
column5: Summarize and describe distributions.
column6: Topic 8: Display, Describe, and Summarize Data
